occurrences.text: mentioned, the psalmist made that great declaration in Psalm 118. We sing the song, but it says, this is the day which the Lord hath made. We will rejoice and be glad in it. And we find here that Habakkuk, if you found your place there in Habakkuk chapter number three, notice in verse 17, notice what the Bible says, although the fig tree shall not blossom. That's not a good situation. The fig tree is supposed to blossom, amen, produce fruit. Neither shall fruit be in the vines. That's unfortunate. The labor of the olive shall fail, and the fields shall yield no meat. The flock shall be cut off from the fold, and there shall be no herd in the stalls. If you read Habakkuk 3 in verse 17, that paints a very, very dim picture. Would you agree? The Bible says that the fig tree shall not blossom, the fruit shall not be on the vines, the labor of the olive shall fail, the field shall yield no meat, the flock shall be cut off from the fold, and there shall be no herd in the stalls. And yet the writer says, yet I will rejoice in the Lord. Habakkuk, did you see what you just wrote in verse 17? Yeah. That's why I said it's purposed, it's intentional. It's a, I'm going to rejoice in the Lord always. I'm going to determine, even in the midst, going through the trials of life, I'm going
